data.title: Get Current Census Data for Aurora, IL
data.meta_description: Need Aurora demographics? Get current population, race, age, income & poverty statistics for Aurora, IL from the US Census Bureau.
data.text:
Sources: United States Census Bureau. 2022 American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates. U.S. Census Bureau, American Community Survey Office. Web. 7 December 2023.

United States Census Bureau. Annual Estimates of the Resident Population: April 1, 2020 to July 1, 2023. U.S. Census Bureau, Population Division. Web. May 2024. http://www.census.gov/.

United States Census Bureau. Annual Estimates of the Resident Population: April 1, 2010 to July 1, 2019. U.S. Census Bureau, Population Division. Web. May 2021. http://www.census.gov/.

United States Census Bureau. "P2 Hispanic or Latino, and Not Hispanic or Latino by Race." 2020 Census State Redistricting Data (Public Law 94-171) Summary File. U.S. Census Bureau, 2020 Census. Web. 12 August 2021. https://www.census.gov/.

Check out our FAQs for more details.

Population

With 177,563 people, Aurora is the 2nd most populated city in the state of Illinois out of 1,450 cities. But watch out, Aurora, because Joliet with 150,489 people and Naperville with 150,245 people are right behind you.

Race & Ethnicity

The largest Aurora racial/ethnic groups are Hispanic (42.3%) followed by White (33.3%) and Asian (10.7%).

Median Income

In 2022, the median household income of Aurora households was $85,943. Aurora households made slightly more than Swansea households ($85,603) and Hamel households ($85,139) . However, 8.6% of Aurora families live in poverty.

Median Age

The median age for Aurora residents is 35.4 years young.
